newsitem.title: USA: Moynihan stadiums bill still troubling - muni groups.
newsitem.headline: Moynihan stadiums bill still troubling - muni groups.

text.p: Nine state and local government groups told U.S. Sen. Daniel Patrick Moyihan on Wednesday that his revised bill to bar use of tax-exempt government bonds to finance professional sports stadiums still goes too far.

The U.S. Conference of Mayors, National League of Cities, National Association of Counties, Government Finance Officers Association, American Public Power Association and others made the charge in a two-page letter to the New York State Democrat.

A bill introduced by Moynihan last year had a June 14, 1995 effective date. His revised version, introduced in late January, sets the date of first action by a House or Senate committee as the effective date. It also would exempt small minor league stadiums, some charitable sports events, and other activities.

But the nine groups said the new bill still has the first bill's "fundamental flaws" even though scores of public officials from New York State and other towms nationwide "brought many legitimate problems to (Moynihan's) attention."

For example, the letter says, public college or university sports complexes that double as practice facilities for professional sports teams would be denied tax-exempt financing under Moynihan's latest bill.

Likewise, public ballparks, tennis facilities, ice skating rinks and other community facilities used occasionally by professionals, including minor league games, could not get tax-exempt financing under the bill, the groups said.

These facilities often are used by an array of nonprofit organizations - from high school and community college teams to American Legion and youth leagues - and are critical to community spirit, the groups said.
The bill would dramatically increase the cost to taxpayers of building new facilities or rehabilitating existing ones, possibly making these projects "simply unaffordable," groups said.
